abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome of the Second
            Road Maintenance and Rehabilitation Project is
            unsatisfactory. Some key lessons include: 1) It is necessary
            to make a realistic assessment of the borrower's
            implementation capacity building institutional risks, ensure
            that strengthening of implementing agencies is carefully
            phased and monitored, and follow up on agreed actions in a
            timely manner. 2) The Bank should continuously monitor
            compliance and commitment of the borrower to provide
            counterpart funds at the highest level, and link those
            levels with reforms of the fiscal/funding mechanisms. 3) The
            borrower should be a partner to policy reforms long before
            the project starts. The Bank should ensure a complete
            understanding of the interdependence of all aspects of the
            reforms program, carefully phase the implementation of
            reforms and focus early implementation on the adoption of
            key reforms, and keep supervision focused on institutional
            issues and monitor achievements in a timely manner. 4) Civil
            works should be implemented in a well-planned manner and
            with clear supervision and monitoring procedures. 5) We
            should include comprehensive local contractors development
            strategies and action plans addressing the specific economic
            issues, and paralleling action plans to strengthen
            operational capacity in road agencies and/or streamlining
            inefficient force account activities. 6) Bank supervision
            should be improved through appropriate staffing.
